Hospital and Health Service/Facility Pandemic Influenza border measures checklist

Overview 
The purpose of Hospital and Health Service/Facility Pandemic Influenza border measures checklist is to quality assure that there are systems and processes in place to prepare for and manage screening of ill travellers at the international border if required. The HHS/Facility Pandemic Influenza border measures checklist has four core elements for assessment and these stipulate the minimum requirements to be met by health service organisations. These core elements include: 

Governance
Standard Operating Procedure
Human Resources 
Environment 

Using the HHS/Facility Pandemic Influenza border measures checklist audit tool 

Step 1: Review (and amend if necessary) the audit tool and determine relevant auditable criteria

Step 2: Conducting the audit using the excel spread sheet insert the following numbering system to determine if the criteria is:

Met = 2
Not applicable = 1
Not met = 0

Step 3: Identify actions required for not met criteria, review date and responsibility

Step 4: Tally each subsection and calculate the percentage of compliance using the following: 
% = (Total items met criteria x 100) / total number assessed items

Step 5: Transcribe scores to Summary Score Sheet

Step 6: Communicate results of the HHS/Facility Border Measures Checklist to relevant meetings and committees

Step 7: Determine when a reaudit needs to occur e.g. annually
A position within the HHS has been delegated responsibility for leading, coordinating and implementing border measures including activation of the Border Measures SOP
A position within the HHS is responsible for developing the Border Measures Standard Operating Procedure (SOP)

Development of the Border Measure SOP includes engagement of key HHS and DoH staff including but not limited to: 
- Public Health
- Infection Prevention and Control
- Occupational Health and Safety 
- Human Resources
- Medical Records area
- Emergency department and other clinical groups as required
- Medical and nursing professionals - Chief Health Officer Branch (if contact tracing plane flights is required when a traveller tests positive for PI)

Engagement of external entities includes but is not limited to the following: 
- Queensland Ambulance Service
- Local international airport
- Local port authority
- Australian Department of Health (for advice)
- Queensland Fire and Emergency Services
Tip: Air/seaport operator will be able to advise contact details for other relevant agencies at the air/seaport e.g.:
- Department of Agriculture 
- Australian Customs Service
- Department of Immigration and Border Protection
- Australian Federal Police
- Air/sea lines
- Aviation Rescue and Fire Fighting (Air Services Australia)
Roles and responsibilities of key stakeholders in regards to border measures and emergency arrangements are clearly defined
There is a defined process for the management of costs associated with staffing Border Measures in the event that there is reimbursement opportunities
The emergency management arrangements at the air/seaport are clearly defined
Communication and reporting pathways are clearly defined before, during and after activation of border measures
There is a timeframe for testing and review of the Border Measures SOP
The Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) clearly outlines the following:
The scope of border measures operations at the air/seaport
Contact details for all key partners, including local administration at the air/seaport
How suspected cases of pandemic influenza will be identified in the absence of positive pratique, passenger locator forms (PLFs), thermal imaging and border nurses
How suspected cases of pandemic influenza will be identified if positive pratique, PLFs, thermal imaging and border nurses are in place
The activities the nurses will undertake at the international air/seaport
The level of care nurses will provide to those being screened e.g. what is the level of resuscitation capability by nurses
There is a process to engage an interpreter if required
There is a process for notifying QAS if required
There is a process for managing medically unstable patients whilst awaiting QAS including indicators for nurses to activate this process
There is a process for requesting medically-stable suspected cases to isolate themselves at home and refer them to support services if required
There is a process established to provide guidance if a symptomatic traveller is in transit to another destination
The process for the collection of nasopharyngeal swabs/aspirates, will this procedure be conducted at the air/seaport? What will the process be if testing is refused?
There is a process for specimens storage whilst awaiting transport to a QH laboratory
There is a process for how suspected cases will be notified of their pathology results

There is a process for how potential contacts (i.e. other passengers and crew) be managed (e.g. will they be permitted to leave the air/seaport with information and only contacted if test results are positive?)
There is a process for tracing travel contacts if a test result is positive for pandemic influenza
There is a process for the provision of antivirals to suspected cases of pandemic influenza at the air/seaport before test results are known
The agency for managing the area and information to be provided to awaiting relatives is identified
There is a process in place for the management of clinical records (e.g. pandemic influenza screening form, antiviral assessment form, standing drug order for antivirals)
Process for maintaining PPE stock for the screening room

Staffing model is developed which includes but is not limited to: 
- recruitment strategy (use of HHS staff, agency staff or other services)
- categories of staff required e.g. medical support, clinical nurses, registered/enrolled nurses, administration staff etc.
- hours to be covered
- shifts and number of staff per shift required
- staff roster template
- HR records and time sheet management 
- reporting sick leave and other leave arrangements (e.g. fatigue leave)

Workplace health and safety provisions and risks have been identified and managed - 
Including not limited to: 
- area layout (including map of areas) 
- air/seaport safety considerations 
- staff security
- clearly identified air/seaport areas that are accessible to HHS staff, including the security clearance process required prior to commencement of a shift. 
- emergency and evacuation procedures 
- travel and parking arrangements
- incident reporting

Training requirements: 
- orientation to air/seaport
- pandemic influenza
- Personal protective equipment - application and removal
- P2/N95 respirator – fit checking 
- Nasopharyngeal swab/aspirate collection
- Antiviral assessment (if antivirals will be supplied to suspected cases at the border)
- Infection prevention and control
- Workplace health and safety 
- identification of ongoing training requirements

Assessment of proposed sites undertaken to ensure that they meet the requirements of the proposed clinic:
- access for delivery vehicles 
-ability of the site to provide unidirectional flow
- site and facility maintenance requirements 
- the ability of the site to be expanded to meet the needs of the area
- availability of hand hygiene facilities
- access to drinking water 
- accessibility by disabled, ambulance stretchers and wheelchairs
- staff and patient/visitor toilets 
- seating at least 1m apart
- waste management facilities

Assessment of access and egress requirements: 
- signage providing public and staff with directions (multi-lingual may be necessary)
- vehicle access and traffic control (e.g. QAS, traffic control)
-separate staff entry point, if applicable
- emergency exits
There is a reception station at the front of the clinic that provides first point of contact with health care personnel at the clinic
There is a registration and waiting area
There is an assessment area and an area for undertaking nasopharyngeal aspirates if indicated.
There is a discharge station for the completion and filling of all documentation
There is a separate staff area
There is a designated area (isolation) for people with flu like symptoms
Area for patient information brochures etc.
There is a process in place for the cleaning of the environment, health technology and equipment

Equipment required for the respective rooms have been identified and may include: 
- Tables, chairs, seats
- Barriers (e.g. tensile)
- Bins and bin liners
- Tissues
- Hand hygiene wash and alcoholic hand gel
- Personal protective equipment 
- Surface wipes 
- Scales (for antiviral dosages titrated to weight)
- Computer (incl. remote access), printer and fax 
- Landline (with speaker function) and mobile phone/s
- Equipment to collect and transport nasopharyngeal swabs/aspirates
- Equipment to provide basic life support
- Resources (e.g. HHS Pandemic Influenza Plan plus relevant SOPs incl. Border Measures SOP, Flu Border Plan, training resources)
- Pens, paper, clipboards, staplers, etc.
